qas.question: In Schwabe and wolfs study what where participants asked to forget?
What were seventy healthy female and male university students, randomly assigned to?

context: However, memory performance can be enhanced <a0_0><b5_0>when material is linked to the learning context<b5_0/>,<a0_0/> even when learning occurs under stress. A separate study by cognitive psychologists Schwabe and Wolf shows <b7_0>that when retention testing is done in a context similar to or congruent with the original learning task<b7_0/> (i.e., in the same room), <a2_0>memory impairment and the detrimental effects of stress on learning can be attenuated.<a2_0/> <b8_0>Seventy-two healthy female and male university students, randomly assigned to<b8_0/> the <b9_0>SECPT stress test<b9_0/> or to a control group, <a3_0>were asked to remember the locations of 15 pairs of picture cards –<a3_0/> a computerized version of the card game "Concentration" or "Memory". The room in which the experiment took place was infused with the scent of vanilla, as odour is a <a1_0>strong <b6_0>cue for memory<b6_0/>.<a1_0/> Retention testing took place the following day, either in the same room with the vanilla scent again present, or in a different room without the fragrance. The memory performance of subjects who experienced stress during the object-location task decreased significantly when they were tested in an unfamiliar room without the vanilla scent (an incongruent context); however, the memory performance of stressed subjects showed no impairment when they were tested in the original room with the vanilla scent (a congruent context). All participants in the experiment, <a4_0>both stressed and unstressed, performed faster when the learning and retrieval contexts were similar.
